(First of two on possible resurgence of fascism in Italy).
This is Graham Hovey, recording in Heme a Letter from Italy for the network of the
National Association of Educational Broadcasters* These programs are produced with the
cooperation of Hadiotelevisione Italians*
At times, I get the uneasy feeling that much of the current political reporting from
Italy for America is out of focus* For years now, we Americans have been getting a steady
flow of articles md broadcasts about the Communist threat to this country* >>e have heard
far less about the threat of a resurgence of Fascism.
Yet, many intelligent Italians, whose implacable opposition to communism is a matter^'?
of record, will tell you that a revival of fascism constitutes the mere serious short-
range threat to the young Italian democracy. And some of these Italians wonder why
Americano concern themselves so little with this Fascist threat.
I always reply that our concern with Italian communism is natural for several reasons.
We have good reason to believe that the Italian Communist party is not basically different
from other Communist parties, excepting that of Yugoslavia* That is, we believe Palmiro
Togliatti and Company are bound hand in glove with Moscow and the Ccn&nformj that the
Italian Communists therefore are a part of a worldwide conspiracy. That fact alone would
make them much more dangerous from our point cf view than the Italian Fascists, who have
no such international organisation* who are not tied to a great power which menaces the
United States and the free world*
Secondly, the Communists and their allies have a demonstrated voting strength far
beyond anything shown thus far by the Fascists* In the last national election, the
Communist© and fellow-traveling Socialists together polled more than 35 per cent of the
votes for the Italian Chamber of Deputies and won a total of 218 seats* The neo-Faecist
Italian Social Movement — or MSI — got less than six per cent of the votes and captured
only 29 seats*
Kven if the Fascist vote percentage were lumped with th -t of the right-wing Monarchist
party, with which it is sometimes allied, the total would fall far below that of the
Communists and Left Socialists*
My Italian friends admit the validity of these arguments, and many of them concede
that the greater lon^-range threat to democracy in Italy is posed by the Communists*
But they also warn that the strength of the Fascist idea or Fascist tactics in Italy
cannot be measured by the number of votes a neo-Faecist party managed to poll in an
election two years ago* For they say that Fascism above everything else is a state of
mind _ and that many Italians who think in Fascist ways actually hold membership in other
parti s, and probably would have little to do with the MSI, the neo-Fascist group.
These Italians say the real threat of fascism in Italy, therefore, is posed not by
the MSI, with occasional help from the Monarchists, but by fascist or totalitarian senti¬
ment existing, say, in the Christian Democratic party’s right wing, or even in the Liberal
party, or in Italians outside any party at the moment*
These arguments came bade to me in a hurry on a recent evening, during fleeting
moments when I almost found myself trapped in the middle of a sou ad of young Fascist storm
troopers on their wry to attack and bomb Communist forty haadqu rters in Home*
